summary: Decimals are fractions written in a special way. To compare decimals, line up the place values and compare digits from left to right.

concepts.title: What is a decimal?
concepts.kid_friendly: A decimal is another way to write a fraction. For example, one half is 0.5.

concepts.title: How to compare decimals
steps: Line up the numbers by the decimal point.
Compare from left to right: ones, tenths, hundredths, thousandths, …
At the first place where digits differ, the bigger digit makes the bigger number.
You can add zeros to the end of a decimal without changing its value (0.5 = 0.50).

worked_examples.title: Compare 0.47 and 0.5
worked_examples.reasoning: Tenths: 0.47 has 4 tenths, 0.5 has 5 tenths → 4 < 5, so 0.47 < 0.5.

worked_examples.title: Compare 3.06 and 3.060
worked_examples.reasoning: Add a trailing zero if it helps: 3.060 = 3.060. Digits match in ones (3), tenths (0), hundredths (6), thousandths (0) → equal.

worked_examples.title: Compare 1.29 and 1.203
worked_examples.reasoning: Ones equal (1). Tenths: 2 vs 2. Hundredths: 9 vs 0 → 9 > 0, so 1.29 > 1.203.

teaching_tips: Use a place-value chart to align digits.
Normalize by adding trailing zeros so both numbers have the same number of decimal places.
Beware of the 'length trick': more digits after the decimal does NOT always mean a bigger number.

exercises.instructions: Compare each pair. Answer with <, >, or =. Show one sentence of reasoning (which place decided it).

easy.explain: Tenths equal (1 vs 1). Hundredths: 9 < (implicit 0? careful) Actually compare as 4.09 vs 4.10 → 09 < 10.

medium.explain: Compare 12.099 vs 12.100 → thousandths 9 < 0 after carrying tenths/hundredths.

challenge.prompt: Put in order from least to greatest: 5.02, 5.2, 5.020, 5.12
A and B are decimals. A = 4.0□, B = 3.99□ (□ is the thousandths digit). For which digits (0–9) is A > B?
challenge.answer: For all digits 0–9. Reason: A ≥ 4.000 and B ≤ 3.999, so A > B always.

challenge.prompt: True or False? If two decimals have the same number of digits after the decimal point, the one with the bigger last digit is larger.
challenge.explain: Counterexample: 2.34 vs 2.40 → last digits 4 < 0 but 2.40 > 2.34 (tenths place decides).
Compare to five decimal places: 7.00050 vs 7.00049 → 50 > 49.

extreme.prompt: Fill the blank digit to make a true statement: 4.3□7 > 4.29□
answers_that_work: All digits 0–9 (left side is already larger at hundredths: 3 > 9 is false—wait!) Correction: Compare tenths then hundredths: 4.3□7 vs 4.29□ → tenths: 3 > 2, so any □ works.
extreme.explain: Once a higher place is larger, lower places don't matter.

extreme.prompt: Two decimals differ only in the thousandths place: 8.540a and 8.540b. If 8.540a < 8.540b, what can you say about a and b?
extreme.explain: First difference is in the thousandths; the larger digit there makes the larger number.
Add another digit at thousandths or beyond to land between.

extreme.prompt: You have three numbers: A=0.400, B=0.40, C=0.4. Put them in order and state if any are equal.
extreme.explain: Trailing zeros do not change value.
